metadata.titleEn: Moho depth and VP / VS in Cathaysia Block
metadata.description:
The data set is mainly shown in the article https://doi.org/10.1016/j.pepi.2019.04.003 The study includes the distribution of the average thickness of the crust and the average velocity ratio of the crust obtained by stacking the P-wave receiver function h-kappa-c of stations in Cathaysia Block.
The dataset contains one file in DAT format: Cathaysia_ moho_ vpvs.dat。
The data set can be used to show the undulation characteristics of Moho in the Cathaysia Block, to see the transverse distribution characteristics of crustal thickness and crustal wave velocity ratio in the Cathaysia Block, and to explore the difference of average crustal composition in the Cathaysia Block.
metadata.instructions:
Data naming: average crustal thickness and Vp/Vs are stored in text format, and the file name is "Cathaysia_moho_vpvs.dat”。
Data reading mode: all ASCII files in the data set can be directly opened by using the text editing software. The main contents: the first column station name, the second column crustal thickness (km), the third column VP / VS, the fourth column crustal thickness estimation error, and the fifth column Vp/Vs error.

literatureList.titleEn: Lithospheric structure in the Cathaysia block (South China) and its implication for the late Mesozoic magmatism
literatureList.referenceEn: Deng, Y., Li, J., Peng, T., Ma, Q., Song, X., Sun, X., ... & Fan, W. (2019). Lithospheric structure in the Cathaysia block (South China) and its implication for the late Mesozoic magmatism. Physics of the Earth and Planetary Interiors, 291, 24-34.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to determine the crustal average thickness and Vp/Vs distribution in a specific region?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method used to determine the crustal average thickness and Vp/Vs distribution involves utilizing P-wave receiver function h-k-c stacking at seismic stations in a specific region to derive the distribution of crustal average thickness and crustal average velocity ratio.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of the data collection methods used to determine crustal thickness and average wave velocity ratios in the Cathaysia region?
Feature Specification.Answer: P-wave receiver functions, h-k-c stacking, average crustal thickness, wave velocity ratios

Quantification.Question: What is the number of dat files included in a dataset related to Moho depth and Vp/Vs ratio in the Cathaysia region?

Comparison.Question: How does the data collection method used to determine crustal thickness and Vp/Vs ratio in the Cathaysia region compare to other methods for measuring similar geological features in terms of accuracy and data resolution?
Comparison.Answer: The method used in the Cathaysia region involves P-wave receiver function h-k-c stacking to obtain average crustal thickness and Vp/Vs distribution, which is particularly useful for illustrating Moho undulation characteristics and lateral distribution of crustal properties. This method may differ in accuracy and data resolution compared to other techniques, such as seismic tomography or direct drilling methods, which can provide varying levels of detail and precision in geological feature measurement.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the variability in crustal thickness and wave velocity ratios in the Cathaysia region, and how might these affect data collection methods?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The variability in crustal thickness and wave velocity ratios across the Cathaysia region can be influenced by geological structures, tectonic activities, and compositional differences within the crust. These factors necessitate the use of specific data collection methods, such as P-wave receiver functions and h-k-c stacking, to accurately capture the average crustal thickness and velocity ratio distributions. The complexity of the region requires careful station placement and data processing to ensure reliable measurements and insights into the crustal composition.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives behind collecting data on Moho depth and Vp/Vs ratios in the Cathaysia region, and how might these insights contribute to understanding crustal composition differences?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to illustrate the undulation characteristics of the Moho surface in the Cathaysia region, providing insights into the lateral distribution of crustal thickness and Vp/Vs ratios. This can further explore the variability in average crustal composition across the region.
